# Introduction

The goal of this project is to predict house prices from the House Sales in King County, USA dataset downloaded from [kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/harlfoxem/housesalesprediction).

The project followed the stages of:

1.  Data Exploration
2.  Splitting the data into training and test set.
3.  Feature extraction and selection of predictors
4.  Modeling: Linear, randomForest and xgboost
5.  Evaluating the models performance and finalizing the results

# Initial data exploration

# Data Preprocessing

```{r remove_vars, include=FALSE, dependson=status}

remove_vars <-  status %>% filter(status$p_zeros > 0.6) %>% pull(variable)
df <- df %>% select(-one_of(remove_vars))
rm(remove_vars, status)
```

As is shown in the table above there are no instances of missing data or values being infinite, however there are a number of variables where the percentage of zeros is greater than 60%, these may not be useful for modeling and they may dramatically bias the model. # Methods/Analysis

## Data split

The first step is to split the data into training and testing datasets. The split will be an 80/20 split with 80% of the data in the training set and the remaining 20% in the test set. The split of the data will be stratified by district, to ensure that the number of data points in the training data is equivalent to the proportions in the original data set.
At some point some parameter tuning will be performed, and to do that cross-validation is used. A cross-validated version of the training set is created in preparation for the parameter tuning.

```{r split_data, echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE}

# Convert price to a log10 value
df <- df %>% mutate(price = log10(price))


# Set the random number stream using `set.seed()` so that the results can be 
# reproduced later. 
set.seed(54321)

# Save the split information for an 80/20 split of the data, stratifying on price
df_split <- initial_split(df, prob = 0.8, strata = price)


df_train <- training(df_split)
df_test  <-  testing(df_split)


# create CV object from training data
df_cv <- vfold_cv(df_train)

# clean up
rm(df_split, M, remove_vars, to_convert)
```

After splitting the data the training set consists of `r nrow(df_train)` row of data and the test set contains `r nrow(df_test)` rows of data. Keeping the training and test set stored in two separate dataframes ensures that information leakages doesn't accidentally occur.

## Linear Regression model

A model is built using price as the outcome . A recipe is created using the [tidymodels](https://www.tidymodels.org/) package.
The predictors used are grade, bedrooms, sqft_living, yr_built and zip_code. Sqft_living is transformed into log10 values to coincide with the price log transformation. Also where the number of bedrooms in the properties is less than 1% of the trainset, these properties are grouped together under the title other.
Once the recipe is created, a specification is defined using lm as the engine for a linear regression model. Finally both the model and recipe are added to a workflow 

```{r df_lm_recipe, echo = FALSE}

df_lm_rec <- 
  recipe(price ~ ., data = df_train) %>%
  step_other(bedrooms, threshold = 0.01) %>% 
  step_log(sqft_living, base = 10) %>% 
  prep()

```



```{r lm_spec, echo = FALSE}

lm_mod <- linear_reg() %>% 
  set_engine("lm")

```

```{r rf_spec, echo = FALSE}
rf_mod <- 
  rand_forest(trees = 1000) %>% 
  set_engine("ranger") %>% 
  set_mode("regression")

```

```{r workflow, echo=FALSE}

wflow <- workflow() %>% 
  add_model(lm_mod) %>% 
  add_recipe(simple_df_rec)

wflow
```

```{r wf_fit, echo = FALSE}

lm_fit <- 
  wflow %>% 
  fit(data = df_train)

lm_fit %>% 
  pull_workflow_fit() %>% 
  tidy()

```

```{r test_res, echo=FALSE}
lm_test_res <- 
  predict(lm_fit, new_data = df_test %>% select(-price))
```

```{r}
estimate_perf <- function(model, dat) {
  # Capture the names of the objects used
  cl <- match.call()
  obj_name <- as.character(cl$model)
  data_name <- as.character(cl$dat)
 
  
  # Estimate these metrics:
  reg_metrics <- metric_set(rmse, rsq, mae)
  
  model %>% 
    predict(dat) %>% 
    bind_cols(dat %>% select(price)) %>% 
    reg_metrics(price, .pred) %>% 
    select(-.estimator) %>% 
    mutate(object = obj_name, data = data_name)
}

estimate_perf(rf_fit, df_train)
estimate_perf(lm_fit, df_train)

estimate_perf(rf_fit, df_test)
```
